titleInfo.title: Analysis of Functional Necessity in Noxious Stimuli
titleInfo.subTitle: The Role of Otoconia in High Magnetic Field Effects and C-Fos Expressing Cells after Lithium Chloride

mods:mods.abstract: In this dissertation I examined 2 stimulus-response model systems involving the neural and behavioral responses to noxious stimuli: 1) high strength static magnetic fields and 2) toxic lithium chloride (LiCl) injections. Static high magnetic fields interact with the vestibular inner ear of rodents and humans. The structures within the inner ear required for the effects of static magnetic fields are largely unknown. We examined the responses of two mutant mouse strains, head-tilt Nox3het (het) and tilted Opt1 (tlt) which show a near complete loss of otoconia in the utricle and saccule. Magnetic fields and other aversive stimuli (such as toxin administration, e.g. LiCl) also induce c-Fos expression in the brainstem. While a useful correlate of neuronal activity, c-Fos expression alone does not establish the functional contribution, if any, of the activated cells to behavioral responses. I bred and validated TRAP2 (Targeted Recombination in Active Population) mice expressing DREADDs (Designer Receptors Exclusively Activated by Designer Drugs) in c-Fos-positive cells, which allows permanent genetic access to the cells activated by acute LiCl or other stimuli. The ability of the DREADD ligand clozapine-n-oxide (CNO) to give animals a taste aversion and the role of c-Fos expressing cells was assessed in a conditioned taste aversion paradigm. By either inhibiting c-Fos cells expressing inhibitory R26-hM4Di DREADD during the pairing of novel saccharin with LiCl, or by stimulating c-Fos cells with excitatory R26-hM3Dq DREADD as a substitute for LiCl paired with saccharin. Het mice lacking otoconia showed no response to magnet exposure: locomotor circling, rear suppression, formation of a taste aversion or significant induction of c-Fos was not observed. However, tlt mice showed some responsiveness to magnet exposure as they show circling behavior but did not form a taste aversion or have rearing suppressed. Otoconia are thus necessary for the full effects of magnet exposure, but the response of tlt mice suggests contribution of semicircular canals The DREADD ligand CNO did not give mice a taste aversion when paired with saccharin as the unconditioned stimulus across several doses up to 30mg/kg. Inhibition of LiCl activated cells blocked the formation of a taste aversion in the inhibitory DREADD expressing mice, suggesting c-Fos expressing populations after LICl administration are necessary for the formation of a conditioned taste aversion.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Program in Neuroscience in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Thomas A. Houpt, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Paul Trombley, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Samuel Grant, University Representative; Johnathan Dennis, Committee Member; Cathy Levenson, Committee Member.
